Award.AwardTitle: Environmental Uncertainties and Livelihood Thresholds in the Okavango Delta, Botswana

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will combine insights from both social and natural sciences to understand how variability and uncertainty in time and space impact human-environment interactions. The project will examine social responses to environmental variability, particularly precipitation and flooding. Of interest is how people maintain their livelihoods, and further how these strategies change in anticipation and in response to environmental change. Thus this work will also characterize the patterns of precipitation and flooding as well as their impacts on household farming, household collection of materials such as reeds, grasses, and wood, and individual entry into the tourism sector. The work will be positioned in the international treaty-recognized Wetland of Importance, the Okavango Delta (OD) of Botswana. Nestled within the Kalahari (Kgaligadi) Desert and flooded each year from Angolan highland precipitation, the OD has experienced vastly dramatic changes in precipitation and flooding in the last several decades. This rural area's population is highly dependent on the natural resource base, either directly (e.g., farming, reed collection) or indirectly (e.g., the wildlife-oriented ecotourism industry). It is therefore further hypothesized that these fluctuations have increased people's uncertainty about the availability of water and the timing / magnitude of flooding, impacting their decisions about which and how many livelihood strategies to employ. The overall project research goals are as follows: 1) quantify environmental change in the OD human-environment system, with particular respect to precipitation and flooding; 2) capture the distribution of natural resources over space and time using field-collected and satellite-derived data; 3) map resource activity areas and management / tenure systems to better understand livelihood decision-making; 4) assess how environmental change impacts livelihood strategy selection, and, in turn, how these decisions impact the environment; and 5) evaluate the utility of a human-environment system framework for understanding dynamic systems such as the OD.

Despite the Okavango Delta's high profile internationally, it has been understudied in terms of the impacts of uncertainty in human perception of and reaction to environmental change in livelihood strategy selection. This work will be of practical and immediate benefit to local and regional resource managers. Collaboration with local researchers will facilitate diffusion of lessons learned to area students, from preschool to university-level. Students from the local University of Botswana campus as well as members of the sampled communities will be trained in survey and GPS (global positioning system) collection, marketable skills which will build capacity for both individuals and communities. The Botswana government maintains permit-approved research results for access by relevant government agencies, thus facilitating better resource management in light of environmental change. Further, results will be distributed through the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands through its Scientific and Technical Review Panel (STRP). Technical Reports are disseminated to all signatory countries to the Convention and will assist in making the research findings available to an international audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project examined the effects of complexly variable environment on livelihoods of ecosystem-dependent people. While many (sub)tropical climates are thought to be seasonless, in fact the last year's hurricane activity impacting US soils indicates that these kinds of environments are often are operating at the margins. Three villages were selected based upon their varying floodplain position: one on a panhandle with more predictable flooding locally but with in-between flood levels rendering both auto and boat traffic risky. The two other villages were selected for their location on either side of the distal portion of the inland alluvial fan, but with different accessibility to roads and therefore tourism (largely ecotourism) for secondary economy or piece work. Local rains can cause flooding, but can come too late for crop success. Upstream rains also cause roughly half a typical flood, reported to vary on a quasi-decadal cycle. When these two flooding sources go in or out of sync, the result can be extended droughts, prolonged flooding, or anything in-between. Further, the low topographic relief in this inland alluvial fan means that waters do not simply expand and shrink along typical flooding stages easily delineated on a map, further complicating people's perceptions and predictions of what the next year's flood would bring, and how best to plan, if at all.

The Intellectual Merit of this work in part comes from learning the system solidly enough to understand the ways in which these seemingly small topographic differences can be directly related to very strong impacts on households and household decision-making, further influenced by the rules of access that sometimes related to culture group and initial settling of an area, increasing the importance of residence time for culture groups most familiar with the cycles. We hypothesized that local people would have novel ways of dealing with variability in when or to what extent flooding occurs. The ways that governance or individual decision-making are involved would have general lessons for understanding how society deals with change that can be surprising, unpredictable, or even harmful to livelihoods. Our Intellectual Merit also grew into part of a broader research initiative that is explicitly interdisciplinary, combining evaluations of how physical and ecological systems change with simultaneous studies of how people are affected by those changes, respond to them, and potentially interact with them. In our case, we used remote sensing to map floodwaters, plus additional information on the location of settlements and lands used for farming, grazing, or harvesting of wild plants. We used vegetation sampling to understand how the land cover in the satellite imagery corresponded to the land uses of the people. Finally, we used household interviews and meetings with local authorities to understand the human dimensions, including how individual people perceive of environmental change, how their households may respond, and if local and national regulations help (or hinder) those efforts. We are striving to make our findings generally relevant for understanding social-ecological systems using integrated mixed methods. allowing comparisons along an axis of flood predictability, useful for thinking holistically about social responses to natural disasters, in particular to livelihood diversification but also in how groups can negotiate assistance through rules of access that may facilitate or dampen their likelihood of receiving timely and helpful recovery assistance. Many times we documented cases where the local people appeared to have the knowledge and capacity to adapt, but rules made from afar did not provide them with the needed flexibility to shift their land use or to diversify their livelihood strategies. However, we also gained insights into other concerns of the people, such as fires, heat waves, or wildlife hazards, and more fundamental concerns such as education, healthcare, and overall wellbeing.

We ended our three years of fieldwork by going back to the three villages studied in detail. We presented our findings, and made sure the local authorities understood what we had done, and if our maps or other data would help them in their tasks. But the most rewarding part was the further interaction with local people, who were polite and interested, but did not hesitate to point additional concerns or complexities involved. This was more than project outreach, it was a way for the researchers to continue learning from the experiences of local residents and we think that as a practice is perhaps the most relevant Broader Impact along with the capacity building of 8 graduate and undergraduate students and 5 local residents in interviewing training. Thus, we suggest that adaptive capacity includes not just perceptions and decision-making, but also the ability to incorporate additional concerns into dealing with environmental variability, with information shared between generations and among settlements with different natural resource endowments. This flexibility could show sustainable social-ecological systems functionality, increasing the generalizability for improved well-being in light of perceived environmental variability and / or uncertainty.
